metadata.titleEn: Landsat normalized difference moisture index (NDMI) products over the Tibetan Plateau (2022)
metadata.description: The dataset is the normalized difference moisture index (NDMI) products of 2022 over the Tibetan Plateau. The dataset is produced based on Landsat surface reflectance dataset. It is calculated by the NDMI equation which use the difference ratio between the NIR band and SWIR2 band to quantitatively reflect the water content of vegetation canopy .And the corresponding production of quality identification documents (QA) is also generated to identify the cloud, ice and snow. NDMI is highly correlated with canopy water content and can be used to estimate vegetation water content, and it is also used to analyze the change of land surface temperature because it is strongly correlated with land surface temperature.
metadata.instructions: 1)File name rules: the NDMI result of each image is stored in a folder including the NDMI band, QA bands, metadata, and browser; the named rule of a folder is presented as "satellite- sensor-path-row-imaging date-LSR-BRDF-NDMI", for example, L8-OLI-131-036-20220326-LSR-BRDF-NDMI;the NDMI is stored as GeoTIFF format and its named rule is presented as "satellite- sensor-path-row-imaging date-LSR-BRDF-NDMI.TIF", for example, "L8-OLI-131-036-20220326-LSR-BRDF-NDMI.TIF". 2)How to use the dataset: the NDMI results can be opened by ArcGIS, Envi, QGIS and so on, the NDMI results are multiplied 10000 to become16 bit integer from the original floating-point type in the range of 0 ~ 1 , so it needs to be multiplied 0.0001 when used, and the background filling value is -9999, and the "LZW" lossless compression is carried out.

background: Glacier mass changes in the Himalayas are a subject of societal concern due to their impact on many large Asian rivers that are relied upon for sustainable water resources; their effect on hazards in downstream regions such as glacial lake outburst floods; and their effect on the availability of Himalayan paleoclimate records from ice cores. Recent studies show that Himalayan glaciers have experienced rapid thinning and shrinkage and that the rates of observed mass changes are spatially and temporally variable. The drivers for the spatiotemporal variability are not well understood and a variety of factors have been proposed to explain it, including debris cover, glacier-lake interactions, morphological variables, climate variability (patterns in air temperature, precipitation, and atmospheric circulation) and the response of individual glaciers to climate variability.
research objective: This study presents the meteorological conditions, energy and mass balance characteristics for Naimona'nyi Glacier on a north-facing slope in the western Himalayas, based on energy-mass balance model and high-altitude measurements from October 2010 to September 2018.
challenges: Some stakes were lost due to glacier surface melt, or were damaged by animals, and some measurements failed due to extremely bad weather. Due to logistical issues, no fieldwork was carried out in 2015.
methods: In October 2010, 39 monitoring stakes were drilled into the ice, distributed across the entire glacier surface. In early October for each year of the study, we manually recorded the stake heights and snow-pit features (snow layer density and stratigraphy) to derive the annual point mass balance. Two automatic weather stations (AWSs) were installed on a lateral moraine beside Naimona'nyi Glacier. AWS1, at 5,543 m a.s.l., recorded meteorological variables from October 2011 at half hourly resolution, including air temperature (Ta), relative humidity (RH), and downward shortwave radiation (Sin). AWS2 was installed at 5,950 m a.s.l. in October 2010 and recorded Ta, RH, Sin, WS, and WD at hourly resolution. Precipitation data was obtained from all-weather precipitation gauges (T-200B) equipped with hanging weighing transducers installed close to AWS2 in September 2013. Two air temperature and humidity sensors (T1 and T2) were installed on Naimona'nyi Glacier in October 2018 at 6,075 and 5,984 m a.s.l., respectively, to measure gradients in air temperature and relative humidity.
dataset: The area of the glacier is 7.34 km2 and it ranges in altitude from ∼5,545 to 7,261.5 m above sea level (a.s.l.). The mass balance was measured using the glaciological method for the northern branch of Naimona'nyi Glacier since 2004. The annual glacier-wide mass balance Ba (m w.e.) is calculated according to:      1 1 , n iii a n ii BSB S (1) where n is the total number of altitude intervals for Naimona'nyi Glacier; Si (m2) is the area for each interval; B i (m w.e.) is the point mass balance at the middle altitude at each individual interval, which is calculated by the interpolation and extrapolation of the point mass balance at stakes.
findings: The average annual mass balance measured for Naimona'nyi Glacier was −0.39 m water equivalent a−1 and point mass balances below 6,070 m above sea level were always negative. Simulations showed that melt during the ablation season dominated the annual mass balance and the interannual variability in the mass balance, and that variability in melt energy was controlled by albedo during the ablation season. The annual mass balance was found to be significantly correlated with annual precipitation during the 2011–2018 period, which is accounted for by the change in ablation-season albedo and melt energy. The average mass balance for glaciers in the western Himalayas were higher during the 2010–2019 period than during the 2000–2009 period, partly because of higher annual precipitation during the 2010–2019 period. Over the last 20 years, the increased precipitation in the cold season was driven by a cyclonic circulation anomaly over the northwestern Indian Peninsula, which may be linked to the strengthened North Atlantic Oscillation, and the increased precipitation in the ablation season was driven by an anomaly in the cyclonic circulation over Central India, which may be related to enhanced deep convection over the Indian subcontinent and the enhanced Atlantic multidecadal oscillation.

Definition.Question: What is the NDMI calculation formula, and how is it used to quantify vegetation canopy moisture content?
Definition.Answer: The NDMI (Normalized Difference Moisture Index) calculation formula utilizes the difference between near-infrared (NIR) and shortwave infrared (SWIR) to quantify vegetation canopy moisture content. This index is particularly useful for reflecting the moisture status in the vegetation canopy.

Definition.Question: What does the term 'glaciological method' refer to in the context of measuring mass balance?
Definition.Answer: The 'glaciological method' refers to a technique for measuring the mass balance of glaciers, which involves using stakes drilled into the glacier surface to manually record changes in stake heights and snow-pit features over time. This method helps derive the annual point mass balance.

Definition.Question: What challenges are commonly associated with data collection in high-altitude glacier environments?
Definition.Answer: Challenges in high-altitude glacier environments include loss or damage of equipment due to glacier surface melt, interference by animals, and failures of measurements due to extreme weather conditions. Additionally, logistical issues can hinder regular fieldwork, as noted in the data collection process for Naimona'nyi Glacier.

Comparison.Question: How does the data collection method for measuring glacier mass balance using a glaciological approach compare to the method of calculating NDMI from satellite imagery concerning their ability to reflect changes in vegetation water content and glacier melt dynamics?
Comparison.Answer: The glaciological method involves direct physical measurements on the glacier using stakes and automatic weather stations to monitor mass changes, while NDMI calculation from satellite imagery quantifies vegetation water content by analyzing differences in spectral reflectance. The glaciological approach provides precise, localized data on glacier mass balance influenced by direct environmental factors, whereas NDMI offers broader spatial coverage and can indirectly relate to glacier dynamics by measuring surface vegetation changes affected by these dynamics.

Interpretation.Question: What considerations should be taken into account when interpreting the variability in NDMI values across different regions of the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Interpretation.Answer: The variability in NDMI values could be influenced by differences in vegetation cover, soil moisture, and meteorological conditions such as air temperature and precipitation patterns. Additionally, the presence of clouds, ice, and snow could affect the quality of the satellite imagery used to calculate NDMI, necessitating careful quality control and data validation procedures.

Interpretation.Question: How might the challenges in measuring glacier mass balance, such as stake loss and extreme weather, impact the accuracy and reliability of long-term climate trend analyses?
Interpretation.Answer: Stake loss and extreme weather can lead to gaps in data and potential inaccuracies in mass balance measurements. These challenges necessitate the use of supplementary data collection methods, such as automatic weather stations and remote sensing, to ensure comprehensive and continuous monitoring. Accurate interpretation of long-term climate trends requires understanding and addressing these potential data collection challenges.

Interpretation.Question: What factors should researchers consider when designing a data collection strategy for monitoring the impact of climatic variations on glacier mass balance in the Himalayas?
Interpretation.Answer: Researchers should consider the spatial and temporal variability of climatic factors like air temperature, precipitation, and atmospheric circulation patterns. The selection of appropriate measurement locations, the use of reliable and durable equipment, and the integration of manual and automatic data collection methods are also crucial. Additionally, researchers must account for logistical challenges and ensure robust data validation and quality assurance processes.

Ensuring data quality is crucial for accurately estimating vegetation water content and analyzing surface temperature changes.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of using NDMI calculations from satellite data to quantify vegetation canopy moisture content in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using NDMI calculations from satellite data can result in accurate estimations of vegetation moisture content, which is crucial for understanding ecological health and changes over time. NDMI's strong correlation with surface temperature can also aid in analyzing temperature variations, providing insights into climate dynamics in the region.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of developing datasets using NDMI from Landsat satellite imagery in the context of the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The ultimate goal of using NDMI from Landsat satellite imagery is to quantify vegetation canopy moisture content. This measure is highly correlated with canopy water content and is often used to estimate vegetation moisture and analyze surface temperature changes.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to monitor the meteorological conditions and mass balance characteristics of Naimona'nyi Glacier using high-altitude measurements and energy-mass balance models?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Monitoring meteorological conditions and mass balance characteristics is crucial for understanding the spatiotemporal variability in glacier mass changes, which have significant impacts on sustainable water resources, hazards, and paleoclimate records in the Himalayas. It helps in identifying drivers such as climate variability and morphological factors.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are involved in the production of NDMI products using Landsat satellite data for the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, and how is data quality ensured?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The NDMI products are produced by calculating the difference between near-infrared and shortwave infrared reflectance from the Landsat surface reflectance dataset. Data quality is ensured by generating quality assurance files that identify clouds, ice, and snow.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the steps taken to measure and calculate the annual mass balance of a glacier, and how is the data used to analyze changes in the glacier over time?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The annual mass balance is measured using the glaciological method, which involves recording stake heights and snow-pit features to derive point mass balance. The glacier-wide mass balance is calculated by interpolating and extrapolating these point measurements across altitude intervals. This data is used to simulate melt patterns and analyze changes in the glacier's mass balance over time, correlating it with precipitation and melt energy variability.

Enablement.Question: What methodologies enable the calculation of NDMI from satellite imagery to assess vegetation water content?
Enablement.Answer: The calculation of NDMI from satellite imagery is enabled by using the difference between near-infrared and shortwave infrared bands to quantify vegetation canopy water content. This process is based on surface reflectance data from Landsat series satellites.

Enablement.Question: How do meteorological data collection techniques at high altitudes improve understanding of glacier energy and mass balance?
Enablement.Answer: Meteorological data collection techniques at high altitudes, such as the use of automatic weather stations and all-weather precipitation gauges, improve understanding of glacier energy and mass balance by providing detailed measurements of air temperature, relative humidity, radiation, and precipitation. This data helps in modeling and analyzing the factors influencing glacier dynamics and their variability.

Expectation.Question: Why might the expected outcomes of NDMI calculations vary when applied to different regions of the Tibetan Plateau using Landsat data?
Expectation.Answer: The variability in expected outcomes of NDMI calculations across different regions of the Tibetan Plateau may be attributed to differences in vegetation cover, moisture content, and climatic conditions affecting the near-infrared and shortwave infrared reflectance values used in the NDMI formula. Additionally, spatial and temporal variations in satellite data acquisition can influence the results.

Expectation.Answer: Automated weather stations (AWS) data may not meet expectations due to potential equipment malfunctions, loss or damage caused by extreme weather conditions, and limitations in capturing localized meteorological variations on glaciers. Furthermore, technical issues in data transmission and calibration can impact data accuracy.

Judgmental.Answer: The integration of NDMI products with other remote sensing data could enhance understanding by providing a more comprehensive view of the vegetation water content and its correlation with surface temperature changes. NDMI is highly related to canopy water content and surface temperature, and by combining it with additional remote sensing data, researchers could better analyze spatial and temporal trends, potentially leading to more accurate predictions and assessments.

Judgmental.Answer: The variability in annual mass balance measurements influenced by precipitation and albedo suggests that these factors significantly affect glacier dynamics. Data collection strategies might need to include more frequent and widespread monitoring of albedo changes and precipitation patterns to capture their impacts accurately.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe the data collection methods used for obtaining meteorological and mass balance data in high-altitude glacier environments.
Request/Directive.Answer: In high-altitude glacier environments, data collection methods include the use of monitoring stakes drilled into the ice to record changes in stake heights and snow-pit features annually. Automatic weather stations (AWSs) are installed to measure meteorological variables like air temperature, relative humidity, and radiation at varying resolutions. Precipitation data is collected using all-weather precipitation gauges with weighing transducers. Additionally, air temperature and humidity sensors are used to measure gradients in these variables on the glacier surface.
